autotune/bandit-introduction.title: Autotune (Bandits)
autotune/bandit-introduction.description: Multi-Armed Bandits are solutions that automatically find the best variant among a group of candidates, balancing between "exploring" options and "exploiting" the best option by dynamically allocating traffic. On Statsig, Bandits are used to pick the best user experience to drive a target metric or action.

autotune/contextual/getting-started.title: Get Started with Autotune AI
autotune/contextual/getting-started.description: Getting started with Autotune AI can be done very quickly.

autotune/contextual/introduction.title: Contextual Bandit (Autotune AI)
autotune/contextual/introduction.description: Contextual Multi-Armed Bandits are a subset of Multi-Armed-Bandits which use context about a user to personalize their experience. This is generally achieved by predicting outcomes from among the variants, and picking the best outcome while factoring for uncertainty. Specifically, they will tend to prefer a slightly worse prediction that has a lot of uncertainty, thereby exploring that variant.

autotune/contextual/monitoring.title: Monitoring your Contextual MAB
autotune/contextual/monitoring.description: There are three primary ways we recommend you monitor autotune performance.

autotune/introduction.title: Autotune (Bandits)
autotune/introduction.description: Autotune and Autotune AI are Statsig's Multi-Armed Bandit solutions that automatically find the best variant among a group of candidates, while dynamically allocating traffic to optimize for a single target metric.

autotune/monitoring.title: Autotune
autotune/monitoring.description: How to monitor your Autotune Test

autotune/using-bandits.title: Advanced Usage
autotune/using-bandits.description: Both contextual and non-contextual bandits are managed on Statsig's console, or through Statsig's console API for programmatic creation. Both bandit types use a common, streamlined API, making it easy to explore either use case without significant changes from using experiments.

azureai/capturing-metrics.title: Capturing Metrics
azureai/capturing-metrics.description: Azure AI SDK automatically captures relevant invocation and usage metrics from each API call and logs them to Statsig.  You can see these events streaming in real-time in the console at//console.statsig.com/metrics/events.

azureai/completions.title: Completions
azureai/completions.description: Chat completions are AI-generated responses used to generate text. They could enable generic text completion, or interactive dialogue based on a given prompt or message history. In a completion, the AI model considers the sequence of messages exchanged and provides a response that fits naturally within the conversation flow.

azureai/embeddings.title: Text Embeddings
azureai/embeddings.description: Embeddings are numerical representations of data (like text, images, or audio) that capture their essential features in a compact form, typically as vectors. For text, embeddings map words or sentences to vector spaces, where similar items are closer together, enabling comparisons and efficient searches. Developers use embeddings in tasks like semantic search, recommendation engines, and clustering, as they allow for analyzing and processing unstructured data with machine learning models that recognize and work with these patterns.

azureai/getting-started.title: Getting Started
azureai/getting-started.description: Step 1: Install the SDK in your server app

azureai/introduction.title: Azure AI
azureai/introduction.description: Statsig offers SDKs for integrating Azure AI models into server applications. These SDKs simplify the implementation of features like completions and embeddings in your server application. They provide easy-to-use APIs and automatically track metrics such as latency, token length, and model details, which you can use for optimization and experimentation. Use cases include:

azureai/model-client.title: AI Model Client
azureai/model-client.description: In order to invoke Azure AI methods, you'll need to instantiate a Model Client.  You have two ways of instantiating a Model Client

azureai/running-experiments.title: Running A/B Tests
azureai/running-experiments.description: Azure AI SDK helps you easily and quickly run A/B tests to measure the effectiveness of different models and related parameters.  By leveraging Statsig's powerful stats engine, you can gain real-time insights into model performance, optimizing for metrics like cost, accuracy, and latency. This integration enables you to experiment with various configurations, such as model type, prompt settings, or response parameters, and make data-driven decisions to enhance your application's efficiency and user experience.

client/concepts/initialize.title: Initializing SDKs
client/concepts/initialize.description: The first step in using a Statsig SDK is calling initialize(), which retrieves the values you need to evaluate experiments & send events. Before initialization, Statsig SDKs won't have latest values in-memory, and therefore may return stale values or none at all.

client/concepts/parameter-stores.title: Parameter Stores
client/concepts/parameter-stores.description: Parameter Stores provide a new way to organize and manage parameters in your web or mobile app via the Statsig console. Now available for JS, React, React Native, Android, iOS, and Dart SDKs on the client side and java, node, python, and rust on the server side.  Let us know in Slack if you'd like support in a certain language soon.

client/concepts/persistent_assignment.title: Client Persistent Assignment
client/concepts/persistent_assignment.description: Persistent assignment allows you to ensure that a user's variant stays consistent while an experiment is running, regardless of changes to allocation or targeting.

client/introduction.description: Statsig client SDKs enable you to run experiments for user experience improvements in applications running on end-user devices. These applications include web and mobile apps, television and gaming apps, and other consumer electronics apps.

developer-guides/abtest-in-python.description: Running a simple A/B experiment in a web page with Python and the Statsig SDK involves a few distinct steps, including creating a basic web server, integrating with Statsig for A/B testing, and configuring the experiment via the Statsig console. Following that, you'll integrate the Statsig SDK to manage feature flags.

dynamic-config/add-rule.title: Adding Rules
dynamic-config/add-rule.description: Add a rule to a dynamic config

dynamic-config/enforce-schema.title: Using a schema
dynamic-config/enforce-schema.description: Dynamic configs support schemas using JSON Schema syntax to enforce a common convention between the return values for each rule you'll set.

dynamic-config/working-with.title: Working with dynamic config
dynamic-config/working-with.description: A dynamic config allows you to use configuration parameters to control the behavior of your application in near real-time.

exp-templates/decision-framework.title: Decision Framework
exp-templates/decision-framework.description: A Decision Framework for experiments allows teams to standardize their interpretation of results and decision-making process. Once configured, it provides clear recommendations for which group to ship based on experimental outcomes. While the framework highlights recommended actions based on metric movements, it does not enforce any actions.

experiments-plus/abandon.title: Abandon an Experiment
experiments-plus/abandon.description: When you realize your experiment has an issue or need to stop it for any reason, you can abandon it. Abandoning an experiment will put it into the unstarted state, which will give every user the default experience back.

experiments-plus/bots.title: Bots
experiments-plus/bots.description: Usually referred to online as feature flags, the Statsig UI and SDKs call them feature gates.

experiments-plus/conclude-experiment-def.description: Conclude the Experiment now and Defer Analysis for later

experiments-plus/create-new.title: Create an experiment
experiments-plus/create-new.description: You're viewing the Cloud docs for this page. Metrics and experiments behave differently in Warehouse Native. Read about Configuring Experiments in Warehouse Native.

experiments-plus/disable-group.description: Disabling a Group in an Experiment

experiments-plus/ending-experiment.title: Ending an Experiment
experiments-plus/ending-experiment.description: For one reason or another, your experiment has come to an end. This could be for a variety of reasons:

experiments-plus/getting-group.title: Getting the Group
experiments-plus/getting-group.description: One common misconception when working with experiments on Statsig is trying to check the experiment group in code.  Checking the experiment group in code is actually an anti-pattern.  It's not necessary with Statsig, and it will limit your ability to quickly test different variants.

experiments-plus/implement.title: Implement an experiment
experiments-plus/implement.description: To deploy an experiment, you'll need to:

experiments-plus/introduction.title: Experiments Overview
experiments-plus/introduction.description: Experimentation is a powerful tool for making data-driven decisions that improve product outcomes and customer experiences.

experiments-plus/make-decision.title: Making the Decision
experiments-plus/make-decision.description: Making a decision for an experiment enables you to 'ship' the winning group to all your users.

experiments-plus/monitor.title: Monitor an experiment
experiments-plus/monitor.description: Once you turn on your experiment, you can monitor the health of your experiment and view the exposures for the control and variants groups.

experiments-plus/overrides.title: Overrides
experiments-plus/overrides.description: Override group allocation for an Experiment

experiments-plus/sequential-testing.title: Frequentist Sequential Testing
experiments-plus/sequential-testing.description: What's the problem with looking early in a "standard" A/B test?

experiments-plus/stop-assignments.title: Stop Assignments
experiments-plus/stop-assignments.description: Stopping New User Assignments in an Experiment

experiments-plus/switchback-tests.title: Switchback Tests
experiments-plus/switchback-tests.description: Switchback tests are an alternative experiment form, whereby an entire population is “switched” back and forth between test and control treatments on a set cadence vs. being split and evenly divided between test and control for the duration of the experiment.

feature-flags/best-practices.title: Best practices for Feature Gates
feature-flags/best-practices.description: Statsig classifies the best practices for using feature gates into four categories: implementation, development, collaboration, and governance.

feature-flags/conditions.title: Feature Gate rule criteria
feature-flags/conditions.description: Statsig feature gates contain a list of rules that are evaluated in order from top to bottom. The page describes in more detail how these rules are evaluated and lists all currently supported conditions.

feature-flags/create.title: Create a Feature Gate
feature-flags/create.description: This guide walks through how to create a Feature Gate in the Statsig console, how to add an evaluation rule to a Feature Gate, how to implement the Feature Gate in your code, examples of common Feature Gate setups, and a list of all Feature Gate targeting conditions available in Statsig.

feature-flags/feature-flags-lifecycle.title: Managing Feature Gate lifecycles
feature-flags/feature-flags-lifecycle.description: A feature can go through different phases throughout its lifecycle - maybe it’s still being tested out by a few users, or only recently fully rolled out to the world, or maybe it’s been tried and true and you no longer need the feature behind a toggle.

feature-flags/overrides.title: Feature Gate overrides
feature-flags/overrides.description: Override results of a feature gate

feature-flags/overview.title: Feature Flags
feature-flags/overview.description: Feature Gates, commonly known as feature flags, allow you to toggle the behavior of your product in real time without deploying new code.

feature-flags/permanent-and-stale-gates.title: Permanent and Stale Gates
feature-flags/permanent-and-stale-gates.description: It is important for your codebase and team to bring feature gates to a final state (i.e. flags now permanently part of your codebase or completely removed) when they have served their purpose, as described here. On Statsig, you can use feature gate Types to easily keep track of your flags that might be ready to brought to their final state.

feature-flags/pre-post-results.title: Pre-Post Results
feature-flags/pre-post-results.description: This feature is currently available only on Statsig Cloud. As we work on a WHN solution, please reach out to Statsig if you're intereseted in being an early customer.

feature-flags/safeguards-create.title: Create a Safeguard
feature-flags/safeguards-create.description: You can create a Safeguard on one or multiple targeting rules within a Feature Gate. To create a Safeguard on a rule, follow the steps below:

feature-flags/safeguards-overview.title: Safeguards
feature-flags/safeguards-overview.description: Safeguards help you ship with confidence by continuously monitoring critical metrics and automatically intervening with a configured rollback/pause/complete action in your Feature Gate rollouts when risk thresholds are exceeded. This ensures faster recovery from issues, eliminating the need for constant manual checks, and protects your users from unintended impact.

feature-flags/scheduled-rollouts.title: Scheduled Rollouts
feature-flags/scheduled-rollouts.description: Feature Gates are powerful in ensuring a safe, controlled feature rollout. Scheduled Rollouts add a time-based scheduling layer to Feature Gates, enabling you to pre-set any rollout schedule you want, which will execute automatically. This is particularly useful if, for example, you have a feature launch happening in another timezone (and don’t want to stay up all night!) or you have a standard, company-wide ramp-up schedule you follow with every feature release.

feature-flags/test-gate.title: Test your Feature Gate
feature-flags/test-gate.description: There are three ways to test your feature gate and to validate that it's working as expected with the rules you have created:

getting-started.title: Getting Started
getting-started.description: Statsig empowers you to ship, measure, and learn from your releases using the same tools as the best tech companies in the world. With Statsig, you can run thousands of A/B tests, safely rollout features, and dive deep on core business metrics and user behavior—all on a single, unified platform.

guides/aa-sidecar.title: Running an A/A (aa) Test using Sidecar
guides/aa-sidecar.description: In this guide, we will walk you through how to leverage Statsig’s sidecar to run an A/A test on your product.

guides/aa-test.title: Running an A/A (aa) Test
guides/aa-test.description: In this guide, you will create and implement an A/A test on your product in Statsig from end to end. This is commonly used to validate a new experimentation engine you may be integrating with.

guides/abn-tests.title: Run your first A/B test
guides/abn-tests.description: In this guide, you will create and implement your first experiment in Statsig from end to end. There are many types of experiments you can set up in Statsig, but this guide will walk through the most common one: an A/B test.

guides/cdn-edge-testing.title: CDN Edge Testing for Cached Resources

guides/config-history.title: Config History
guides/config-history.description: History for entities like Feature Gates, Experiments, Dynamic Configs, and Segments can be accessed by clicking the "History" button on the top right of the page.

guides/contentful.title: Guide to Contentful
guides/contentful.description: The Statsig Contentful integration lets you create A/B/n tests and test different content blocks against each other directly from within Contentful. You can assess impact using business metrics on Statsig Cloud or Warehouse Native. Marketers can optimize content, obtain insights, and iterate continuously right from within Contentful.

guides/customer-io-email-abtest.title: Email AB Testing with Customer.io
guides/customer-io-email-abtest.description: Email campaigns are a critical tool for any Marketing team.  Finding the best performing Email template is a perfect use-case for an A/B test.  Statsig allows you to run simple but powerful A/B tests on different parts of your email content.  Since Statsig can integrate seamlessly with product analytics, you can run email experiments and understand deeper business level impact on product metrics easily.

guides/email-campaign-test.title: A/B Test Email Campaigns
guides/email-campaign-test.description: A/B Testing an email campaign and getting experiment results on downstream product metrics (in addition to top level email interaction metrics), is a common use case for Statsig customers. Email marketing tools often have native A/B testing capabilities, but are limited to measuring email open rates or link click rates.

guides/experiment-on-custom-id-types.title: Experiment on custom Unit ID types
guides/experiment-on-custom-id-types.description: In certain cases, you may want to randomize experiment bucketing using a custom Unit ID instead of the default userID or Statsig-generated Stable ID. For instance, if you're running a task management tool for companies and want to experiment on company-wide behaviors, you might use companyID as the Unit ID. This ensures all users from the same company get the same experience, allowing you to measure overall productivity impacts at a company level.

guides/experimentation-program.title: Bootstrapping Your Experimentation Program
guides/experimentation-program.description: In this guide, we'll outline a straightforward and successful approach to starting an experimentation program using Statsig at your company. Best of all, you can get started completely free with Statsig’s free tier, which includes up to 5M events per month and no limit on the number of team members.

guides/experiments.title: Experiment Types on Statsig
guides/experiments.description: This guide provides a quick overview of  experiment types we've seen people run on Statsig.

guides/feature-flags.title: Create your first feature flag
guides/feature-flags.description: This tutorial walks you through how to create your first feature flag in Statsig from end to end. Feature flags are a way to safely control the rollout of new features to your users without deploying additional code. Common examples for using feature flags include shipping new UI elements, API endpoints, or product features. In Statsig, we refer to feature flags as Feature Gates to distinguish them from other flagging and feature management tools in the product.

guides/featureflags-or-experiments.title: When to use Feature Flags vs. Experiments?
guides/featureflags-or-experiments.description: With Statsig, you can create control and test groups and compare them using A/B testing via either feature gates or experiments. This guide helps clarify when to use a feature gate versus an experiment, depending on your needs.

guides/first-device-level-experiment.title: Build your first Device-level Experiment
guides/first-device-level-experiment.description: When you cannot identify a user via their user ID, device-level experiments allow you to randomize experiments based on a consistent identifier for the user's device. While Statsig can automatically generate a stable ID, it's recommended to use your own cookie or logged-out ID when possible.

guides/first-dynamic-config.title: Making Your Code More Flexible with Dynamic Config
guides/first-dynamic-config.description: Now that you have created your Statsig account, and perhaps even your first feature, this guide will help you make your app a bit more flexible with Dynamic Config.

guides/first-feature.title: Build your first Feature
guides/first-feature.description: Usually referred to online as feature flags, the Statsig UI and SDKs call them feature gates.

guides/first-segment.title: Reusable Targeting with User Segments
guides/first-segment.description: User Segments allow you to predefine targeting groups for re-use in Feature Gates and Dynamic Configs. Think of it as a reusable macro for a set of users.

guides/fomo.title: Commonly Used Features on Statsig for Enterprise Customers

guides/landing-page-experiments/introduc.title: Landing Page Experiments
guides/landing-page-experiments/introduc.description: This tool is being deprecated in favor of using Sidecar for running Landing Page and split URL experiments.

guides/landing-page-experiments/setup.title: Setting up Landing Page Experiments
guides/landing-page-experiments/setup.description: This tool is being deprecated in favor of using Sidecar for running Landing Page and split URL experiments.

guides/landing-page-experiments/webflow.title: Using Webflow to run Landing Page Experiments

guides/migrate-from-amplitude.title: Migrate your analytics data from Amplitude
guides/migrate-from-amplitude.description: Migrating from Amplitude to Statsig is a strategic choice. Statsig is an all-in-one platform that offers analytics, experimentation, and feature flagging under one umbrella. Using all these products in a single tool is much more powerful.

guides/migrate-from-mixpanel.title: Migrate your analytics data from Mixpanel
guides/migrate-from-mixpanel.description: Switching from Mixpanel to Statsig is a smart move for teams seeking a unified platform that combines analytics, experimentation, and feature flagging. This all-in-one approach empowers faster, more informed decisions without data silos.

guides/migration-overview.title: Migration Overview
guides/migration-overview.description: Statsig combines feature flags, experimentation, and product analytics in one platform. Migrating ensures your data, flag, experiments, and decision workflows live in a single source of truth.

guides/node-express-abtests.title: Experimenting in NodeJS ExpressJS
guides/node-express-abtests.description: ExpressJS is a fast, minimalist framework for NodeJS.

guides/node-express-feature-flags.title: Feature Flags in NodeJS ExpressJS
guides/node-express-feature-flags.description: ExpressJS, renowned for its efficiency and minimalist design, is a cornerstone framework for NodeJS developers. This guide focuses on integrating feature flags in NodeJS ExpressJS applications using Statsig's NodeJS Server SDK. Discover how to enhance your ExpressJS app with feature flags for flexible and dynamic user experiences.

guides/open-source-script.title: Open Source Script
guides/open-source-script.description: This package is designed to help automate migration of feature flags from LaunchDarkly to Statsig. It fetches feature flags from LaunchDarkly, translates them into Statsig's format, and creates corresponding feature gates in Statsig.

guides/private-attributes.title: Using Private Attributes
guides/private-attributes.description: Evaluating feature gates, dynamic configs, segments, and experiments without logging user data to Statsig

guides/production.title: Moving from POC to Production
guides/production.description: This guide introduces the steps for transitioning from a proof of concept (POC) or limited test on Statsig to a full-scale production deployment.

guides/python-flask-abtests.title: Run an A/B Test with Python Flask
guides/python-flask-abtests.description: Python Flask, a popular lightweight framework, is not only user-friendly but also robust enough for consumer-facing applications. One of the exciting capabilities it offers is the ability to conduct A/B tests efficiently. In this guide, we'll demonstrate how you can A/B test with Python Flask using Statsig's free tier, an essential tool for dynamic web application development.

guides/python-flask-feature-flags.title: How to set up Feature Flags in Python with Flask
guides/python-flask-feature-flags.description: Discover how easy and efficient it is to implement feature flags in your Flask applications. Flask, Python's lightweight web framework, is an excellent choice for developers looking to integrate feature flags into their projects. This guide walks you through the process using the Python Server SDK, demonstrating how Statsig's tools can enhance your Flask projects.

guides/sendgrid-email-abtest.title: Email AB Testing with SendGrid
guides/sendgrid-email-abtest.description: Email campaigns are a critical tool for any Marketing team.  Finding the best performing Email template is a perfect use-case for an A/B test.  Statsig allows you to run simple but powerful A/B tests on different parts of your email content.  Since Statsig can integrate seamlessly with product analytics, you can run email experiments and understand deeper business level impact easily.

guides/seo-testing.title: SEO Experimentation with Statsig
guides/seo-testing.description: In late 2017, Airbnb's growth team faced a deceptively simple question:

guides/serverless.title: Using Statsig in Serverless Environments
guides/serverless.description: In this guide, we will walk you through how to leverage Statsig’s platform in serverless environments.  The examples in this guide use the statsig-node SDK in a Google Cloud Function.

guides/setting-up-reviews.title: Setting up Reviews for Team Workflows
guides/setting-up-reviews.description: You can enable reviews for all Statsig resources such as feature gates, dynamic configs, segments, and experiments that you'll likely deploy to a production environment.

guides/sidecar-experiments/creating-expe.title: Creating your first experiment
guides/sidecar-experiments/creating-expe.description: Sidecar allows you to create and run A/B experiments easily without having to write code or push code to production.  Here we'll see how you can create one such experiment and get results

guides/sidecar-experiments/integrating-g.title: Integrating Sidecar with GTM for tracking
guides/sidecar-experiments/integrating-g.description: This integration is for tracking purposes only. We strongly advise against loading Sidecar itself via GTM, as this will delay the changes from being applied and result in "flickering".

guides/sidecar-experiments/publishing-ex.title: Taking your experiments to production
guides/sidecar-experiments/publishing-ex.description: With the experiment configuration out of the way, we need to take this to production.  Sidecar makes this easy with just a few clicks.

guides/sidecar-experiments/setup.title: Setting up Sidecar
guides/sidecar-experiments/setup.description: * This guide assumes you have an existing Statsig account.  Please go here to create a new free account if you don't already have one//statsig.com/signup

guides/synchronized-launch.title: Synchronizing Multiple Feature Launches
guides/synchronized-launch.description: As you get used to developing with feature flags, you will start to include them from the beginning of your feature development, changing the audience of your features as you go.  As this takes hold across your team/organization/company, you will want to be able to tie features together and launch them simultaneously, as part of a broader release.

guides/testing.title: Testing your Configurations on Statsig
guides/testing.description: Statsig enhances your engineering velocity by offering tools and features that allow you to test configurations quickly while ensuring reliable outcomes. This page highlights key features across the product to help you test efficiently.

guides/ui-based-tool.title: UI-Based Tool
guides/ui-based-tool.description: You can follow this guide to use Statsig's built in LaunchDarkly migration tool. Please note that this UI-based tool only imports the "production" environment at the moment.

guides/uptime.title: Paranoid about uptime? 9 things to do!
guides/uptime.description: Statsig serves billions of individual user interactions. Along the way, we designed the service for reliability and availability of your apps that use Statsig. Because of this, in the case where your application cannot reach Statsig for any reason, your application will continue to work exactly as you expect with locally cached values.

guides/using-environments.title: Using Environments for Conditional Evaluation outside of Production
guides/using-environments.description: Statsig SDKs allow you to set the environment tier for your app during initialization. This helps you evaluate feature gates, dynamic configs, and experiments differently in non-production environments like development or staging. All you need to do is configure the appropriate environment in your code and adjust feature rules in the Statsig Console.

guides/webflow-sidecar-ab-test.title: A/B Testing with Webflow and Sidecar

holdouts/introduction.title: Holdouts
holdouts/introduction.description: Holdouts measure the aggregate impact of multiple features. It involves a "holdout" group of users that are held back from a set of features for measurement. While each A/B test or experiment you run compares control and test groups for that feature, a holdout compares the "holdout" group (Control) against users who have been exposed to multiple features and experiments.

http-api.title: HTTP API
http-api.description: ⚠️ Important: While this HTTP API is available for direct use, we strongly recommend using one of our official SDKs for your programming language whenever possible. SDKs offer better performance, automatic error handling, and type safety. They also provide a more idiomatic integration with your codebase. Only use this HTTP API directly if there isn't an SDK available for your language or if you have a specific use case that requires direct API access.

infra-analytics/events-mode-logs-explore.title: Events Mode on Logs Explorer
infra-analytics/events-mode-logs-explore.description: Events Mode brings the searching and filtering abilities from Log Explorer to your existing Statsig events data. No additional instrumentation required!

infra-analytics/getting-started.title: Getting Started with OTEL + Statsig
infra-analytics/getting-started.description: This guide helps you setup and send OpenTelemetry telemetry to Statsig so you can use Infra Analytics (Logs Explorer, Metrics Explorer, Alerts).

infra-analytics/logs-explorer.title: Logs Explorer
infra-analytics/logs-explorer.description: Logs Explorer provides a way for you to search and analyze all of your product’s logs in one place. It works for logs, traces, and ingested events, so you can use the same interface whether you’re debugging infra issues or investigating product event streams.

infra-analytics/logs-explorer-queries.title: Query Syntax
infra-analytics/logs-explorer-queries.description: Use queries to filter, combine, and visualize logs with precision. This page covers common syntax you can use in day-to-day investigations, plus a few ready-to-edit examples.

infra-analytics/overview.title: Statsig Infra Analytics Overview
infra-analytics/overview.description: Infra Analytics helps you monitor and debug the health of your services directly inside Statsig. It pulls in logs, metrics, and alerts so you get system-level observability in the same place you analyze product outcomes.

infra-analytics/topline-alerts-logs.title: Topline Alerts with Logs
infra-analytics/topline-alerts-logs.description: Detect regressions in your infrastructure by evaluating logs in real time. You can use them to monitor request success rates, error codes, or other log-derived metrics.

infrastructure/api_proxy/introduction.title: API Proxy
infrastructure/api_proxy/introduction.description: This section provides documentation on the various API proxy options supported when using Statsig.

infrastructure/api_proxy/managed-proxy.title: Statsig Managed API Proxy
infrastructure/api_proxy/managed-proxy.description: An API proxy gives you a unique URL to send and receive data to/from Statsig servers.  This makes it less likely to be intercepted by client-side or DNS-side blockers.  This way you'll be able to get the right configuration for your applications and more data back from your applications.

infrastructure/introduction.title: Infrastructure Operations
infrastructure/introduction.description: Statsig's infrastructure is the foundation that enables reliable feature flagging, experimentation, and analytics at enterprise scale. When you're running experiments that impact billions of users or managing feature flags for critical business logic, infrastructure reliability is essential to your product's success.

infrastructure/monitoring.title: Monitoring the SDK
infrastructure/monitoring.description: This latest release of structured logging and metrics, is currently only available by the Python SDK. Want it in another? Reach out in our Support Slack.

infrastructure/reliability-faq.title: Reliability FAQs
infrastructure/reliability-faq.description: Integrating your product with Statsig means depending on Statsig, and we take reliability seriously. Here are some questions many people have when trying to evaluate the risks, please feel free to reach out on Slack if you have questions that are not listed here.

infrastructure/statsig_domains.title: Statsig Domains
infrastructure/statsig_domains.description: Statsig uses the following domain names for its services. If you have a network policy set up inside your systems, you should allowlist

infrastructure/statsig_ip_ranges.title: Statsig IP Ranges
infrastructure/statsig_ip_ranges.description: Statsig reserves the following IP addresses and ranges for use by its services. If you have a network policy set up inside your systems, you should allowlist

insights/aggregated-impact.title: Metric Insights and Aggregated Impact
insights/aggregated-impact.description: Statsig's Insights page provides a clear view of how experiments and feature gates impact a specific metric of interest. It not only helps answer key questions such as "How much impact have I driven?", but also serves as a powerful tool for diagnosing unexpected changes in metrics.

integrations/data-connectors/google-anal.title: Google Analytics
integrations/data-connectors/google-anal.description: Enabling the Google Analytics 4 integration allows Statsig to send logged events and exposures to GA4. This enhances your existing Google Analytics tracking with additional data collected by Statsig's logging SDKs.

integrations/data-connectors/segment.title: Segment
integrations/data-connectors/segment.description: Enabling the Segment integration for Statsig will allow Statsig to pull in your Segment events. This allows you to run your experiment analysis on Statsig with all of your existing events from Segment without requiring any additional logging.

integrations/data-imports/azure_upload-d.title: Azure Metrics Upload (Deprecated)
integrations/data-imports/azure_upload-d.description: This solution is still functional, but can be manual and time consuming to set up with minimal error handling. We encourage you to check out the Data Warehouse Ingestion solution instead.

integrations/data-imports/bigquery-depre.title: BigQuery (Deprecated)
integrations/data-imports/bigquery-depre.description: This solution is still functional, but can be manual and time consuming to set up with minimal error handling. We encourage you to check out the Data Warehouse Ingestion solution instead.

integrations/data-imports/overview-depre.title: Imports Overview (Deprecated)
integrations/data-imports/overview-depre.description: This solution is still functional, but can be manual and time consuming to set up with minimal error handling. We encourage you to check out the Data Warehouse Ingestion solution instead.

integrations/data-imports/redshift-depre.title: Redshift (Deprecated)
integrations/data-imports/redshift-depre.description: This solution is still functional, but can be manual and time consuming to set up with minimal error handling. We encourage you to check out the Data Warehouse Ingestion solution instead.

integrations/data-imports/snowflake-depr.title: Snowflake (Deprecated)
integrations/data-imports/snowflake-depr.description: This solution is still functional, but can be manual and time consuming to set up with minimal error handling. We encourage you to check out the Data Warehouse Ingestion solution instead.

integrations/event_filtering.title: Event Filtering
integrations/event_filtering.description: Once you've enabled an integration, you can select specific events that you want to send and/or receive by clicking on the Event Filtering button.

integrations/gtm.title: Google Tag Manager (GTM)
integrations/gtm.description: Inbound Integration (Events flow from GTM dataLayer to Statsig)

integrations/introduction.title: Introduction
integrations/introduction.description: For Warehouse Integrations, go to this page.

integrations/mcp.title: Statsig MCP Server
integrations/mcp.description: The Statsig MCP (Model Context Protocol) server lets tools like Cursor and Claude Desktop read directly from the Statsig API. With this setup, you can ask questions, explore experiments, and access your Statsig data using AI.

integrations/pulumi.title: Pulumi
integrations/pulumi.description: The Statsig Pulumi Provider allows you to configure your gates and experiments using Pulumi Infrastructure as Code. The provider synchronizes with Statsig via the Console API. If there is something you need to perform that isn't supported by the Pulumi Provider, checkout the Console API.

integrations/slack.title: Slack
integrations/slack.description: The Statsig Slack integration lets you receive updates where your team already works. You can connect Slack to get project-level, team-level, or personal notifications.

integrations/terraform/introduction.title: Statsig Terraform Provider
integrations/terraform/introduction.description: The Statsig Terraform Provider allows you to configure your gates and experiments with Terraform. The provider synchronizes with Statsig via the Console API. If there is something you need to perform that isn't supported by the Terraform Provider, checkout the Console API.

integrations/terraform/terraform_experim.title: Managing Experiments With Terraform
integrations/terraform/terraform_experim.description: You can create a .tf file (Terraform File) to configure your Statsig experiments. All features of console/v1/experiments are supported. The layout is very similar to the JSON body of a /experiments request.

integrations/terraform/terraform_gate.title: Managing Gates With Terraform
integrations/terraform/terraform_gate.description: You can create a .tf file (Terraform File) to configure your Statsig feature gates. All features of console/v1/gates are supported. The layout is very similar to the JSON body of a /gates request.

messages/serverSDKConnection.title: How do server SDKs handle a failure to connect with Statsig?

metrics/101.title: Metrics - Overview
metrics/101.description: You're viewing the Cloud docs for this page. Metrics and experiments behave differently in Warehouse Native. Read more in Data & Semantic Layer in Warehouse Native.

metrics/201.title: Overview
metrics/201.description: In this 201-level user guide, you'll learn to create your own metrics and organize them as your project grows. You'll also be able to customize the definition of your daily active users (DAU).

metrics/archiving-metrics.title: Archiving and Deleting Metrics
metrics/archiving-metrics.description: Statsig offers two ways to manage the end-of-life for your metrics.

metrics/autogenerated.title: SDK autogenerated metrics
metrics/autogenerated.description: In addition to automatic exposure logging, the statsig-js sdk logs events to help diagnose the impact of new features.

metrics/console.title: Metrics Dashboard
metrics/console.description: Metrics are available for all unit types enabled in the project.  User ID and Stable ID are provided by default and others can be added following these steps.  Make a selection from the drop down to view event DAU and user accounting metrics calculated based on the desired unit type.

metrics/create.title: Creating Custom Metrics
metrics/create.description: Custom metrics are computed by Statsig from your raw events. To create custom metrics, navigate to Metrics from the left-hand navigation panel, then to the Metrics Catalog tab. Tap on the Create button.

metrics/create-metric-tags.title: Creating Metric Tags
metrics/create-metric-tags.description: To create a metric tag, click on Metrics in the left hand navigation menu, and click on the Metrics Catalog tab.

metrics/create-user-flows.title: User Flows
metrics/create-user-flows.description: Statsig's User Flows enable you to visualize customer journeys through your application.

metrics/create-user-funnels.title: Funnel Metrics
metrics/create-user-funnels.description: You can create a custom funnel metric, from either the Custom Metrics creation wizard in the Metrics Catalog or via the Charts tab.

metrics/custom-dau.title: Custom DAU Metric Creation Guide
metrics/custom-dau.description: This guide will walk you through the steps to create a custom DAU metric. Follow

metrics/custom-metrics.title: Custom Metrics
metrics/custom-metrics.description: You can create Custom Metrics using the custom events you ingest by filtering or aggregating events based on event metadata. You must include metadata along with the custom events when you log these events with Statsig.

metrics/different-id.title: Cluster Experiments - Running Analysis Across Unit Types
metrics/different-id.description: There are two common scenarios where the experiment assignment unit differs from the analysis unit:

metrics/directionality.title: Metric Directionality
metrics/directionality.description: By default, increases to a metric value are assumed to be 'good', and are represented by a green color in Experiment results. However for many metrics, it’s actually a good thing when the metric decreases and similarly bad to see an increase (e.g. page load times or many performance metrics)

metrics/hierarchical-id.title: Cohort Metrics
metrics/hierarchical-id.description: If your IDs have a "one-to-many" or "root-to-leaf" relationship, you can do two kinds of analysis

metrics/how-metrics-work.title: How Metrics Work on Statsig
metrics/how-metrics-work.description: You're viewing the Cloud docs for this page. Metrics and experiments behave differently in Warehouse Native. Read more in About Warehouse Native.

metrics/introduction.title: Metrics
metrics/introduction.description: Statsig combines data from any of your existing data sources to give you a complete view of your product metrics as well as the impact new features and experiments have on these metrics.

metrics/metric-dimensions.title: Event Property
metrics/metric-dimensions.description: Statsig enables you to breakdown metrics into a single set of non-overlapping dimensions for deep dive analyses.

metrics/pulse.title: Pulse Metrics
metrics/pulse.description: Experiments with Statsig use Pulse to compute and communicate results. The metric type is important in computing and interpreting the final result.

metrics/raw-event-metrics.title: Auto-generated Metrics
metrics/raw-event-metrics.description: Metrics are critical for monitoring the health and usage of your product as well as the impact of new features and experiments.

metrics/raw-events.title: Raw Events
metrics/raw-events.description: Statsig uses the raw events emitted by your application to compute a wide range of product metrics. These events contain the context you need to understand user behavior and infer their intentions.

metrics/rollout-alerts.title: Rollout Alerts
metrics/rollout-alerts.description: When rolling out a new feature or experiment, you may want to be notified if your rollout or experiment regresses a metric beyond a pre-set threshold. Statsig enables this via Rollout Alerts.

metrics/user-dimensions.title: User Property
metrics/user-dimensions.description: It is  helpful to be able to break down Pulse results by user properties like Free vs Paid, or OS type. Setting User Property lets you slice data by properties like this.

metrics/verified.title: Verified Metrics
metrics/verified.description: This is an Enterprise feature, please reach out to our support team, your sales contact, or via our slack channel if you want this enabled.

org-admin/experiment_policy.title: Experiment Policy
org-admin/experiment_policy.description: Organization level Experiment Policies are an Enterprise only feature.

org-admin/gates_policy.title: Feature Gates Policy
org-admin/gates_policy.description: Organization level Feature Gate Policies are an Enterprise only feature.

org-admin/organization_policies.title: Organization Policies
org-admin/organization_policies.description: Organization-level Experiment and Gate Policies are an Enterprise only feature.

product-analytics/alerts.title: Alerts Overview
product-analytics/alerts.description: Statsig offers two types of alerts on the platform today:

product-analytics/overview.title: Product Analytics Overview
product-analytics/overview.description: Statsig product analytics helps you understand how your users experience and interact with your product through the analysis of product data. Metrics Explorer and Dashboards are the primary product analytics surfaces within Statsig.

product-analytics/topline_alerts.title: Topline Alerts
product-analytics/topline_alerts.description: Topline Alerts notify you when key metrics shift beyond a threshold or change in value. They are available in Statsig Cloud and Statsig Warehouse Native.

pulse/access-whn.title: Export Pulse Results to Your Warehouse in Warehouse Native
pulse/access-whn.description: How to Access Pulse Data in Warehouse Native

pulse/best-practices.title: Best Practices and Avoiding False Positives
pulse/best-practices.description: We have some suggestions on how to interpret Pulse in a scientifically-sound way:

pulse/best-practices-whn.title: Best Practices and Avoiding False Positives

pulse/export.title: Exporting Pulse Reports
pulse/export.description: How to Export Pulse Data in Statsig Cloud

pulse/faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions on Using Pulse
pulse/faq.description: Interpreting statistical results can be tricky, and often people will have similar questions as we ramp up. Here's some answers!

pulse/faq-whn.title: Frequently Asked Questions on Using Pulse

pulse/userproperties.title: Slicing by User Properties
pulse/userproperties.description: Statsig let's you slice results by user properties. Common examples of doing this include breaking down results by user's home country, subscription status or engagement level.

quickstarts/check-gate.title: Create your first feature flag
quickstarts/check-gate.description: This tutorial walks you through how to check your first Feature Gate in Statsig from end to end. Feature Gates, also known as feature flags, are a way to safely control the rollout of new features to your users without deploying additional code. Common examples for using Feature Gates include shipping new UI elements, API endpoints, or product features.

release-pipeline/actions.title: Manage an Ongoing Release Pipeline
release-pipeline/actions.description: Once a Release Pipeline is triggered, you can control its progression using the following actions. These controls allow you to safely test, pause, fast-track, or halt propagation of feature gate and config changes across pipeline phases.

release-pipeline/create-and-manage.title: Create and Manage Release Pipelines
release-pipeline/create-and-manage.description: A Release Pipeline must be defined before it can be used by feature gates or dynamic configs during the rollout process.

release-pipeline/overview.title: Release Pipeline Overview
release-pipeline/overview.description: Release Pipelines enable sophisticated, multi-stage rollout strategies that respect your infrastructure boundaries, providing greater control over feature deployments.

release-pipeline/trigger.title: Trigger a Release Pipeline
release-pipeline/trigger.description: A Release Pipeline is activated when you make changes to a feature gate or dynamic config that has a pipeline attached to it.

sdk-keys/target-apps.title: Target Apps
sdk-keys/target-apps.description: Target Apps are an Enterprise-only feature. Reach out to our support team, your sales contact, or via our slack channel if you want this enabled.

sdks/array-operators.title: Array Operators
sdks/array-operators.description: Array operators allow for checking if an array custom field does or does not contain specific values

sdks/build-with-llms.title: Build with LLMs
sdks/build-with-llms.description: If you are using AI assistants / coding agents in your workflows, then use this guide to accelerate how you work with Statsig in your application.

sdks/client-vs-server.title: Client vs Server SDKs
sdks/client-vs-server.description: Statsig offers client and server SDKs to enable experimentation and feature management across different parts of your application. This document outlines when you should choose each.

sdks/getting-started.title: SDK Overview
sdks/getting-started.description: Statsig's SDKs are the in-code tool you'll use to show experiment variants, flag your features, and log your key business metrics. Statsig's SDKs:

sdks/pagination-params-breaking-change.title: Requiring Pagination Parameters in API List Endpoints

sdks/quickstart.title: Get started with the Statsig SDK
sdks/quickstart.description: This quickstart will guide you through quickly installing the Statsig SDK in a client app. If you're looking for a more detailed guide, check out the SDK Overview or read about choosing between client or server SDKs.

sdks/support.title: SDK Support Policy
sdks/support.description: To ensure the security, performance, and reliability of our SDKs, we only provide official support for SDK versions that are less than one year old from their release date, unless otherwise specified (some updates may require a different timeline or migration path).

segments/add-rule.title: Adding Rules
segments/add-rule.description: Create a rule for a segment

segments/use-segment.title: Using a segment
segments/use-segment.description: You can use a segment to target a set of users in a feature gate or a dynamic config as follows:

server-core/go/migration.title: Migrating from Legacy Go SDK to Go Core
server-core/go/migration.description: This guide will help you migrate from the legacy Go Server SDK to the new Go Core SDK. The Go Core SDK offers significant performance improvements and new features, as it's built on a shared Rust core library.

server-core/java/migration.title: Migrating from Legacy Java/Kotlin SDK to Java Core
server-core/java/migration.description: This guide will help you migrate from the legacy Java/Kotlin Server SDK to the new Java Core SDK. The Java Core SDK offers significant performance improvements and new features, as it's built on a shared Rust core library.

server-core/legacy-sdks.title: Legacy Server SDKs
server-core/legacy-sdks.description: Statsig is in the process of transitioning to the new Statsig Server Core architecture, which unifies all Server SDKs around a unified, performance optimized core package. We expect this model will support both superior performance and greater feature consistency across SDKs.

server/concepts/all_assignments.title: Getting All Assignments Instantaneously
server/concepts/all_assignments.description: Our SDKs are designed to be invoked in your code at the point where you're serving the experiment treatment or feature.

server/concepts/cloudflare.title: Ingesting Cloudflare Logs and Metrics into Statsig

server/concepts/data_store.title: Server Data Stores  / Data Adapter
server/concepts/data_store.description: One common question when configuring Statsig is how to design your integration around handling potential points of failure. For example - in case of a Statsig API outage, can my integration continue to function?

server/concepts/open_telemetry.title: Ingesting Open Telemetry Logs and Metrics into Statsig
server/concepts/open_telemetry.description: Setting up OTEL can be tricky, if you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us on slack!

server/concepts/persistent_assignment.title: Server Persistent Assignment
server/concepts/persistent_assignment.description: Persistent assignment allows you to ensure that a user's variant stays consistent while an experiment is running, regardless of changes to allocation or targeting.

server/deprecation-notices.title: Deprecation Notices
server/deprecation-notices.description: Direct Initialization API Access for Server SDKs, October 31, 2025

server/introduction.title: Server SDKs
server/introduction.description: Statsig server SDKs allow you to run experiments for server-side functionality such as APIs, algorithms, configurations, and infrastructure improvements. The server SDKs evaluate feature gates, dynamic configurations, and experiments locally on your application server.

server/node/upgrade_guide/v5ToV6UpgradeG.title: Node SDK v5.x.x to v6.0.0 Upgrade Guide

session-replay/cli-session-replay.title: CLI Session Replay
session-replay/cli-session-replay.description: CLI Session Replay allows you to record terminal sessions in your Node.js CLI applications and replay them in the Statsig Console. This enables you to understand how users interact with your command-line tools, diagnose issues, and improve the user experience.

session-replay/install.title: Install Statsig Session Replay
session-replay/install.description: Session Replay is supported on the Javascript or React SDKs for both desktop and mobile web users on your web application. See the instructions below to install our SDK and record user sessions.

session-replay/overview.title: Session Replay Overview
session-replay/overview.description: Session Replay allows you to record users using your website or product, and play back those recorded sessions. This allows you to better understand how users use your service or website, diagnose problems, and uncover insights that help improve conversion and the overall user experience.

session-replay/watch.title: Watch Session Replays
session-replay/watch.description: Session Replays can be found under the User’s group in the Statsig console’s navigation panel.

siggy/gate-management.title: Walkthrough guide for Gate Management with CLI
siggy/gate-management.description: The walkthrough guide assumes you have Statsig CLI installed and configured with the right API keys.  Please refer to the Statsig CLI Overview to get started

stats-engine/confidence-intervals.title: Confidence Intervals
stats-engine/confidence-intervals.description: Confidence intervals are an intuitive way to quantify the uncertainty in the observed metric deltas. A 95% confidence interval should contain the true effect 95% of the time. This means that if we ran an experiment 100 times, the true value of the metric delta should be inside the confidence intervals 95 times.

stats-engine/methodologies/one-sided-tes.title: One-Sided Test
stats-engine/methodologies/one-sided-tes.description: One-Sided Tests (aka One-Tailed Test, Non-Inferiority Test)

stats-engine/p-value.title: p-Value Calculation
stats-engine/p-value.description: In Null Hypothesis Significance Tests, the p-value is the probability of observing an effect larger than or equal to the measured metric delta, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is true. In practice, a p-value that's lower than your pre-defined Type I Error threshold ($\Large\alpha$) is treated as evidence for there being a true effect.

stats-engine/pre-experiment-bias.title: Pre-Experiment Bias
stats-engine/pre-experiment-bias.description: In some cases, users in two experiment groups can have meaningfully different average behaviors before your experiment applies any intervention to them. If this difference is maintained after your experiment starts, it's possible that experiment analysis will attribute that pre-existing difference to your intervention.

stats-engine/topline-impact.title: Topline and Projected Impact
stats-engine/topline-impact.description: The topline impact is the average daily effect that an experiment has on the overall metric value as compared between two groups. This is the real daily impact to a metric resulting from running the experiment, measured amongst the two groups being evaluated. The projected launch impact is an estimate of the daily impact we expect to see in the metric measured globally if a decision is made and the test group is launched to all users (beyond just those in the experiment). This impact is computed relative to the expected baseline value of the metric if the experiment wasn't running at all.

stats-engine/variance.title: Standard Error & Mean Variance
stats-engine/variance.description: The standard error (sometimes denoted "SE" or "std err") of the mean of each group is required for computing the confidence interval and p-value of a metric delta between those groups. The standard error of the mean can be obtained by dividing the sample standard deviation of $X$ by the square root of the number of users in the group.

statsig-warehouse-native/analysis-tools/.title: Egress, Privacy, & Storage
statsig-warehouse-native/analysis-tools/.description: Understand how Statsig uses your warehouse

statsig-warehouse-native/analysis-tools/.title: Pipeline Overview
statsig-warehouse-native/analysis-tools/.description: Understand what we're running on your warehouse

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/a.title: Assignment Sources
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/a.description: Assignment Sources are how you schematize your assignment data for Statsig, and they serve as the input data for determining who is in an experiment, and which treatment they got.

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/c.title: WHN Console API
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/c.description: Statsig's console API allows you to programmatically perform CRUD operations on all of the configuration objects above. This means you can do bulk, programmatic edits, or use the API to sync your definitions into Statsig as a triggered or scheduled job.

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/d.title: Data & Semantic Layer
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/d.description: When using Statsig Warehouse Native, you configure metrics, experiments, and other schematized data objects that allow Statsig to perform analysis on top of your warehouse.

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/m.title: Metric Examples
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/m.description: For customers transitioning from other Warehouse Native Vendors, the format of metrics should be similar and generally customers have been able to use APIs to fetch remote configurations, translate them, and post them to Statsig without issue.

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/m.title: Metric Sources
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/m.description: Metric Sources are how you schematize your warehouse data for Statsig, and they serve as the input data for metrics.

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/q.title: Macros
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/q.description: In Metric and Assignment sources, you can use Statsig Macros to directly inject a DATE() type which will be relative to the experiment period being loaded.

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/s.title: Semantic Layer Sync
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/s.description: If you have centrally defined metrics, Statsig offers the ability to sync its data sources and metrics as part of your data version management workflow. Using Statsig's Console API you can automatically sync changes you make to the matching definitions on Statsig, and you can optionally make the metrics read-only in the Statsig console.

statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/t.title: Tags & Teams
statsig-warehouse-native/configuration/t.description: Statsig offers tools to enrich data sources, metrics, and entities with team ownership as well as arbitrary tags. These provide a powerful way to organize your data configuration, and also feed into advanced analytics tools like meta-analysis.

statsig-warehouse-native/connecting-your.title: Clickhouse Connection [Beta]
statsig-warehouse-native/connecting-your.description: The Clickhouse connector for warehouse native is fully functional, but some functionality may not be performance-optimized or may have minor syntax errors until the beta period is over.

statsig-warehouse-native/connecting-your.title: Forwarded Data
statsig-warehouse-native/connecting-your.description: If you log events or exposures to Statsig's SDK, Statsig will put that data back in your warehouse in near-realtime, on-demand.

statsig-warehouse-native/connecting-your.title: Trino Connection [Beta]
statsig-warehouse-native/connecting-your.description: The Trino connector for warehouse native is fully functional, but some functionality may not be performance-optimized or may have minor syntax errors until the beta period is over.

statsig-warehouse-native/cure/introducti.title: CURE
statsig-warehouse-native/cure/introducti.description: CURE (variance Control Using Regression Estimates) is Statsig's extended implementation of CUPED, a technique which uses pre-experiment data for each experimental unit to control some of the data observed in an online experiment. CUPED can reduce variance moderately to significantly, and can correct for some amount of pre-existing differences between experiment groups at the time of the experiment.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/autotu.title: Autotune (Beta)
statsig-warehouse-native/features/autotu.description: Autotune Experiments in Warehouse Native have a very similar setup to cloud Autotunes. In Warehouse Native, Autotune success events will be pulled from a Metric Source, and computation of results will happen in your warehouse.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/config.title: Configuring Experiments
statsig-warehouse-native/features/config.description: Setting up an experiment is a core flow in Statsig. In Warehouse Native, there's two modes to setting up an experiment. In one, you'll connect to existing assignment data from your warehouse. In the other, you'll configure the experiment in Statsig, use the Statsig SDK, and then analyze the resulting exposures in your warehouse.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/entity.title: Entity Properties
statsig-warehouse-native/features/entity.description: Provide additional details about given entity

statsig-warehouse-native/features/experi.title: Configuring Experiments
statsig-warehouse-native/features/experi.description: In Statsig Warehouse Native, there's a large amount of configurability in experiment setup and analysis. Statsig users should be able to run an experiment with "default" options and get powerful, trustworthy statistical analysis of your results, but in many cases an advanced configuration helps users maximize power and helps to measure exactly what is intended to be measured.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/full-r.title: Full Reloads
statsig-warehouse-native/features/full-r.description: Full reloads will completely wipe the Staging/Results Datasets Statsig has used for previous pulse calculations, and Statsig will recalculate results from scratch.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/funnel.title: Funnel Metrics
statsig-warehouse-native/features/funnel.description: Use funnel metrics to understand user journeys

statsig-warehouse-native/features/id-res.title: Advanced ID Resolution
statsig-warehouse-native/features/id-res.description: Map cross-platform IDs in experiment analysis and analyze anonymous user experiments

statsig-warehouse-native/features/increm.title: Incremental Reloads
statsig-warehouse-native/features/increm.description: Incremental reloads save state from the last load, and load from the latest data read with a small buffer to ensure completeness. This job wipes data since the last load, plus that buffer, and then appends all new data to the staging datasets before calculating results for changed days.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/metric.title: Metric Reloads
statsig-warehouse-native/features/metric.description: Metric reloads drop all data from staging pipelines associated with a metric, and restate that data from scratch. Where this data is interconnected (e.g. ratios, funnels, etc.), related entities will be updated as well.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/mex-on.title: MEX on Warehouse Native [Beta]
statsig-warehouse-native/features/mex-on.description: Metrics Explorer (or MEX) is Statsig's Analytics solution. With Warehouse Native, this integrates directly on top of your tables to provide easy analysis on the same datasets you're using for experimentation.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/other-.title: Other Features
statsig-warehouse-native/features/other-.description: Many features are not listed within the Warehouse Native section since they function near-identically between Cloud and Warehouse Native. These are worth exploring as you integrate with Statsig:

statsig-warehouse-native/features/power-.title: Power Analysis
statsig-warehouse-native/features/power-.description: Determine your experiment duration with confidence

statsig-warehouse-native/features/roles-.title: Roles
statsig-warehouse-native/features/roles-.description: Statsig has custom, configurable RBAC (role-based-access-control) across console. This is especially useful for warehouse native customers, as you can control who can update which metrics as well as visibility into raw data.

statsig-warehouse-native/features/statis.title: Statistics
statsig-warehouse-native/features/statis.description: Statsig's statistics engine is designed to deliver the best analysis of experiment results in the market. We have four core values around our Stats Engine: Transparency, Trust, Flexibility, and Power

statsig-warehouse-native/features/turbo.title: Turbo Mode
statsig-warehouse-native/features/turbo.description: Use turbo mode to reduce cost

statsig-warehouse-native/features/types-.title: Types of Experiments
statsig-warehouse-native/features/types-.description: Statsig offers many forms of Experiment Analysis, detailed below:

statsig-warehouse-native/features/unders.title: Understanding Experiments
statsig-warehouse-native/features/unders.description: Running statistical analysis for an experiment can be complex. Much of this complexity is abstracted away from the end user, but this commonly leads to questions - things like:

statsig-warehouse-native/features/use-ca.title: Practical Use Cases
statsig-warehouse-native/features/use-ca.description: How can I define and filter results to 'new users' only?

statsig-warehouse-native/geotests/geotes.title: Get Started with Geotests
statsig-warehouse-native/geotests/geotes.description: This guide walks you through creating a Geotest experiment using Statsig. The steps include:

statsig-warehouse-native/geotests/introd.title: Geotests
statsig-warehouse-native/geotests/introd.description: Sometimes you just can't run an A/B test at a per-user level. Some common causes are:

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/aatest.title: Synthetic A/A Test
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/aatest.description: To create a quick A/A test, you can randomly split existing users you already have events for. Create an assignment source using the script below - and you;ll be ready to analyze your A/A test in minutes and see Pulse scorecards light up.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/best-pra.title: Data Best Practices
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/best-pra.description: Best Practices for using Statsig in your warehouse

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/checklis.title: Setup Checklist
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/checklis.description: After you've connected your warehouse and set up both metrics and assignment sources, you can ensure your setup is complete and correct by checking the following items:

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/cloud2wh.title: Cloud to Warehouse Native Migration
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/cloud2wh.description: This page gives you a quick overview of what migrating from Statsig Cloud to Statsig Warehouse Native looks like. If you are an enterprise customer on Statsig Cloud and want to use Statsig Warehouse Native please work with your Statsig contact to evaluate feasibility. If all (or most) of your metrics come from your data warehouse already, migration can be straight forward. Migration only changes where metrics are computed - they are sourced in your warehouse with WHN.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/connect.title: Connect Your Warehouse
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/connect.description: To run analysis on your warehouse, Statsig needs to connect to your warehouse via a service user. You control the access this user gets to your warehouse. In general, Statsig will require:

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/costs.title: Warehouse Costs
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/costs.description: How you can manage costs with statsig

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/email-ex.title: Running Email Experiments
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/email-ex.description: Email marketing experimentation is a common use-case that can be handled elegantly by using Statsig Warehouse Native to analyze the downstream outcomes that occurred as a result of an email experiment.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/metrics.title: Metrics
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/metrics.description: This documentation page may be out of date, but is being kept for reference. Please refer to the newer documentation here.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/playgrou.title: How to Run a Playground Evaluation
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/playgrou.description: Due to the effort involved in setting this up, this section only applies to Enterprise tier evaluations (not for free or pro tier)

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/pulse.title: Pulse
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/pulse.description: Pulse is Statsig's visualization of how an experiment impacted target metrics. This page walks through the tool and how to use it to evaluate your experiment.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/quick-st.title: Warehouse Native Quickstart
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/quick-st.description: You can get experiment results in record time with Statsig Warehouse Native. This page walks you through connecting your data, configuring a metric, and getting experiment results.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/running_.title: Running a Warehouse Native POC
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/running_.description: The purpose of this guide is to give a general overview of how to plan a proof of concept with Statsig Warehouse Native (WHN). This guide articulates the high level components of our solution, the steps required for a customer to successfully lead a proof of concept and validation/next steps to move forward with a productionization.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/scaling.title: Scaling Warehouses (β)
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/scaling.description: You can now connect multiple Snowflake warehouses to your account, enabling better query performance by automatically distributing query jobs across all available warehouses. To set it up, you can head over to Settings > Project > Data Connection, and select Set up additional Warehouses.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/sdks.title: Working With the SDK
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/sdks.description: Warehouse Native Works with any of Statsig's SDKs for logging events and getting feature flags or experiment assignments.

statsig-warehouse-native/guides/sql.title: View SQL
statsig-warehouse-native/guides/sql.description: Statsig Warehouse Native runs SQL in your warehouse to generate the experiment results, and the queries are fully transparent and made visible in console. This means that you can trace any results you see on the Statsig console back to its calculation, artifacts, and raw events.

statsig-warehouse-native/introduction.title: About Warehouse Native
statsig-warehouse-native/introduction.description: Statsig Warehouse Native is an enterprise-grade experimentation platform that runs analysis in your data warehouse. It integrates easily with your existing datasets and any source of experiment assignment data – including a powerful integration with Statsig's SDKs and real-time logging infrastructure.

statsig-warehouse-native/metrics/funnel.title: Funnel++
statsig-warehouse-native/metrics/funnel.description: Funnel++ is a Statsig Warehouse Native feature.

understanding-platform.title: Statsig Platform Overview
understanding-platform.description: What do I use Statsig for?

users/introduction.title: Users Tab
users/introduction.description: The Users section of Statsig gives you an event-by-event level understanding of how users (and other Unit IDs) are leveraging your product. This allows you to diagnose issues and understand user behavior at an extremely granular level with event logs, session streams, and session replays. It is also a singular place to manage feature rollout and experiment overrides.

users/user-profiles.title: User Profiles
users/user-profiles.description: User Profiles are a collection of properties about the people using your product. In Metrics Explorer, you can join these profile properties with any event for analysis and segmentation. Previously, user properties had to be present on each event you wanted to analyze. Now they live independently on the user profile, letting you:

webanalytics/autocapture.title: Autocapture on the Web
webanalytics/autocapture.description: The JavaScript, React, and Angular SDKs support autocapture, which automatically captures events and their attributes without requiring you to manually instrument your code.

webanalytics/overview.title: Statsig Web Analytics Overview
webanalytics/overview.description: Web analytics lets you track and watch key measures for your website easily. It is different from product analytics because it's simpler and more direct, making it great for marketers, web site maintainers, or anyone familiar with tools like Google Analytics.
